sn3.14:4.2: Then King Ajātasattu Vedehiputta of Magadha mobilized an army of four divisions and marched to Kāsi to attack King Pasenadi of Kosala.
sn3.14:4.3: When King Pasenadi heard of this,
sn3.14:4.5: he mobilized an army of four divisions and marched to Kāsi to defend it against Ajātasattu.
sn3.14:4.6: Then the two kings met in battle.
sn3.14:4.7: And in that battle Ajātasattu defeated Pasenadi,
sn3.14:4.8: who withdrew to his own capital at Sāvatthī.
sn3.14:5.1: Then several mendicants got dressed in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
sn3.14:5.2: Then, after the meal, when they returned from alms-round, they went up to the Buddha,
sn3.14:5.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn3.14:5.4: and told him what had happened. Then the Buddha said:
sn3.14:7.1: “Mendicants, King Ajātasattu has bad friends, companions, and associates.
sn3.14:7.2: But King Pasenadi has good friends, companions, and associates.
sn3.14:7.3: Yet on this day King Pasenadi will have a bad night’s sleep as one defeated.”
sn3.14:7.4: This is what the Buddha said. …
sn3.14:8.4: having left victory and defeat behind.”
